text: Sir Nicholas George Winton MBE (born Nicholas George Wertheim; 19 May 1909 - 1 July 2015) was a English-born Jewish stockbroker, banker, and humanitarian of German descent, who saved the lives of many Czech Jewish children from 14 March to 2 August 1939, by transporting them from Czechia to Sweden and England. He was also known as the "British Schindler". The transports lasted almost five (5) months, in total. He was never awarded Righteous Among The Nations by the Yad Vashem, because he never risked his lives to save the Jews, which would actually be against one of the policies required by the Yad Vashem in Israel. For all of his actions and responsibilities, he was knighted by Queen Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom, for his service, in the year, 2003. Winton was born in Hampstead, London, England. His parents were German Jews. The family later became Christians and Winton was baptised. In 1923, he began studying at Stowe School. He married Grete Gjelstrup, a woman of Danish origin, in 1948. They were married until Gjelstrup's death in 1999. They had three children together, Nicholas, Barbara and Robin. Archived. Winton died from respiratory failure on 1 July 2015 in Slough, Berkshire, aged 106. ==References== ==Other websites== * Category:1909 births Category:2015 deaths Category:British bankers Category:British centenarians Category:British Jews Category:English activists Category:English Christians Category:Humanitarians Category:Jewish activists Category:Jewish businesspeople Category:Members of the Order of the British Empire Category:People from Hampstead Category:Stockbrokers
